key_behaviors: Uses Perplexity, Google Gemini, and Microsoft Copilot for personal tasks
Uses AI tools about once a month
Employs AI for vacation planning and explores using it for software development at home
Attempts to use AI browser (Perplexity Comet) for information gathering
Seeks AI assistance for email organization and management of large inboxes
Envisions AI as a personal IT consultant for various life‑automation tasks
pain_points: Security and privacy concerns when granting AI access to personal data or systems
Current AI integrations (e.g., Gmail Gemini) are too limited to handle large email volumes and complex actions
Difficulty prioritizing ideas and deciding which projects to start, leading to inaction
Tools are either overly general and risky or overly narrow and not useful for desired tasks
Lack of clear guidance on how to safely use AI features (e.g., AI browser, email automation)
Annoyances in AI interview platforms such as mandatory video and fiddly start/stop recording
Limited rapport and conversational feel in AI‑driven surveys
trust_factors: Higher trust when AI operates in a constrained, well‑defined context
Reduced trust due to perceived security risks and uncertainty about AI over‑reaching its permissions
desires: An AI that encourages faster typing and improves collaboration skills
Resource‑optimization assistance (selling unwanted items, finding recyclers, disaster preparedness)
Comprehensive financial aggregation and account‑security management
A personal IT consultant capable of safely integrating with calendars, email, and other personal systems
Ability to toggle between survey‑style efficiency and conversational rapport depending on user preference

verbatim_quotes.quote: Perplexity, Google Gemini, Microsoft Copilot
Monthly
vacation planning for far-future vacations
assistance with software development, the vibe coding thing.
some thoughts about the timelines, about when the best time or the least latest responsible time would be to make certain decisions.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Value derived from AI in planning

verbatim_quotes.quote: Partly, it's a prioritization issue about what to work on first, and then it's just time.
I have too many ideas, so I have a hard time picking one, which leads to not starting
I did try one of the AI browsers. I think it was Perplexity Comet.
given some of the security concerns, I stopped.
I don't want to give AI access to everything because there's some concern about whether it will go ahead and use something it doesn't need access to anyway
I want a personal IT consultant, but it just seems so much more limited than that, and I can't really think in that box or outside that box or take those kinds of actions.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desire for a more capable personal assistant

verbatim_quotes.quote: I would like its help organizing my email, deleting all the stuff that doesn't really matter
I would say frequently.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Frequency of mismatch between expectations and reality

verbatim_quotes.quote: 3 - Moderate trust
It would encourage me to type faster.
It would motivate me to learn how to collaborate better with it and other people.
It would help me optimize my resources.
It would assist me in selling my unneeded items and getting them shipped.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Desired capability – logistics for unwanted items

verbatim_quotes.quote: It would help me find other people to assist me in doing things I want to do, like selling my unneeded items and finding good places to recycle things.
It would help me keep all my accounts secure.
It would help me gather all my financial information together in one spot.
It would help me prepare for disasters.
Well, I think mostly it would be about increasing brain space and positive energy.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Overall benefit of an ideal assistant

verbatim_quotes.quote: Compared to a human, there was certainly less rapport, less social obligation, and more convenience for me.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Experience of AI interview vs human

verbatim_quotes.quote: There was the requirement for the video, but it seemed not to really be used.
The interviewer was writing the questions in more of a survey style than a chat style
I would say I don't think there is an ideal. It would be nice to have one that you could control, depending on your audience.
I lean more towards survey, and I just don't think the well, certainly, I've seen other platforms implement it better.
I'm anti-anthropomorphizing AI, so I prefer more of a survey approach and less of the pretending to be human equivalent.

unique_insights: The participant frames AI as a "personal IT consultant" that could offload mundane logistics (email triage, selling/unneeded items, recycling, disaster prep, financial aggregation) to free up "brain space and positive energy" for creative work. Unlike many users who seek conversational rapport, this participant explicitly prefers a survey‑style, low‑anthropomorphized interaction and wants the ability to toggle interaction modes based on audience. Security concerns are not just about data leakage but about AI taking unintended actions to achieve a goal, which heavily limits willingness to grant broader permissions.
